column1: Owls Sweep UTSA on Senior Night
column2: BOCA RATON, Fla. ‚Äì Florida Atlantic volleyball closed out regular season play on Friday, earning a straight-set sweep against the UTSA Roadrunners, 3-0 (26-24, 25-21, 25-21), on Senior Night inside Eleanor R. Baldwin Arena. The Owls close out the regular season at 19-10 and 10-6 in American play, while UTSA falls to 13-13 overall and 6-9 in conference play. HOW IT HAPPENED UTSA took the early advantage, leading 5-2, but a 4-0 FAU run gave the Owls their first lead of the match after a kill from Anna Hartman, 6-5. After a 10-10 tie, the Roadrunners retook the lead, holding a two-point advantage, 15-13, through the opening media break. UTSA extended its lead to 19-16, forcing the Owls to call their first timeout of the match, but following the break, the Owls scored three unanswered off a pair of Roadrunner errors and an ace from Erin Morrissey to tie the set at 19-19 and spark a UTSA timeout. The Roadrunners held set point at 24-22, but two kills from Hartman and one from Morrissey powered a set-ending 4-0 run as the Owls took the opening set, 26-24. The Owls fell into a hole early in the second, trailing 12-5 to open the set. Florida Atlantic battled back, outscoring the Roadrunners 10-3 to fight back and tie things up at 15-15 after a kill from Maggie Allred, sparking UTSA to call a timeout. The two squads battled back and forth through a tight 22-21 FAU lead, but the Owls recorded back-to-back kills from Libby Ashline, Olivia Hart, and Kayla Richardson to secure the second set, 25-21, and give FAU the two-set lead. Unlike the first two sets, Florida Atlantic came out firing in the third, opening the period on a 13-6 run. The Roadrunners battled back to cut the Owls' lead to three at 14-11, but FAU responded on a 4-1 run to extend its lead back to six, 18-12, and spark the Roadrunners to call a timeout. UTSA attempted to rally, battling back within two at 19-17 and 23-21, but the Owls capitalized on a pair of Roadrunner errors to close out the third, 25-21, and secure the straight-set sweep. STATS & NOTES Hartman led the way offensively for the Owls with a team-high 11 kills in the match. Emsley Venard finished with a team-best 21 assists. Isabelle Northam led the Owls' back row, recording a match-high 14 digs. Allred paced the Owls at the net, tallying a team-high four blocks in the win. As a team, the Owls led the Roadrunners in kills (41), assists (39), and service aces (6). FAU also held an advantage in side-out percentage, outpacing UTSA 61.8 percent to 54.1 percent. UP NEXT With the regular season in the books, the Owls will now prepare for the American Volleyball Tournament on Nov. 21-23 in Tampa, Florida, at the Yuengling Center. Tournament matchups and seeding will be finalized after the final regular season matches on Sunday. FOLLOW THE OWLS To stay up to date with everything Florida Atlantic volleyball, follow @FAUVolleyball on X and Instagram, or like FAU Volleyball on Facebook.

column1: Owls Come Up Short Against Green Wave
column2: NEW ORLEANS ‚Äì In its final road contest of the 2025 regular season, the Florida Atlantic football team fell to American Conference contender Tulane by a score of 35-24 on Saturday afternoon. The Owls (4-6, 3-4) were led by redshirt junior QB Caden Veltkamp, who set the individual single game program record in both completions (39) and attempts (57) while throwing for a season best 375 yards. He was assisted in the passing game by career best outings from redshirt junior WR Easton Messer (133 yards) and redshirt sophomore WR Asaad Waseem (11 receptions). VIDEO RECAP FIRST HALF Florida Atlantic's offense marched right into Green Wave (8-2, 5-1) territory on the opening drive, halted by an interception in the end zone. The defense forced consecutive three-and-outs before Tulane capitalized on a fumbled punt return and scored on the next play. The Owls put points on the board on the following possession, set up by Veltkamp finding Messer on a first-and-23 who turned a pass short of the sticks into a 50-yard gain. The drive led to a field goal from redshirt senior K Garrison Smith. After another Tulane touchdown to close the first quarter, Florida Atlantic responded with a 75-yard drive culminating in Veltkamp finding redshirt junior WR Jayshon Platt on fourth-and-goal for his third straight game with a receiving touchdown to narrow the gap to 14-10. The Green Wave scored once more to send the Owls to the locker room trailing 21-10. SECOND HALF FAU's defense stopped Tulane on two consecutive drives, first forcing a punt at midfield and then an interception by freshman DE Josh Roberts, before a touchdown late in third quarter extended the Green Wave lead to three scores. Not going down without a fight, Florida Atlantic put together another 75-yard scoring drive finishing with a score by sophomore RB Kaden Shields-Dutton from one yard out to cut the deficit to 28-16. While Tulane found the end zone one more time with under five minutes to go, the Owls had one more drive left in them. Veltkamp connected with Messer for an 11-yard touchdown and Waseem for the ensuing two-point conversion. The onside kick came up short, leaving the 35-24 final. OFFENSE Veltkamp has thrown for 300+ passing yards in four games, most by an Owl quarterback in a single season since Chris Robison in 2019. Through 10 games in 2025, he is now eight completions away from setting the program's single-season record. Messer had his third 100+ yard game of the season, reaching 117 in the first half alone. He has hauled in 83 catches in 2025, now second all-time in program history for a single season. Platt is the first Florida Atlantic player to log a receiving touchdown in three straight games since LaJohntay Wester in 2022. Redshirt junior WR Dominique Henry recorded career highs in both receptions (six) and yards (78). DEFENSE Leading in tackles with a double-digit performance for the second week in a row was redshirt junior LB Leon Hart Jr. with 13, also notching 1.5 tackles for loss. Roberts' interception was the Owls' third of the season. Junior DE Deshaun Batiste and redshirt junior CJ Doggette Jr. joined forces for a sack. POSTGAME AUDIO Hagerty Family Head Football Coach Zach Kittley Sophomore RB Kaden Shields-Dutton PHOTO GALLERY Gallery: (11-15-2025) Florida Atlantic at Tulane UP NEXT Florida Atlantic returns home for the final two games of the 2025 regular season, first hosting Connecticut on Saturday, Nov. 22 at Flagler Credit Union Stadium. The afternoon will be one of commemoration and recognition for the program's 300th game. Kickoff is at 3 p.m. on ESPN+. FOLLOW ON SOCIAL Stay informed by reading FAUSports.com or through social media accounts @FAUFootball.

CHARLOTTE, N.C. ‚Äì Florida Atlantic men's soccer defeated FIU 3-2 on Saturday to capture the 2025 American Conference Postseason Tournament title. The victory is the program's second conference championship all-time and first since the 2007 Atlantic Soccer Championship. The start of Saturday's Championship Final was ominous for the Owls. FIU scored the opening goal just three minutes in after a mad scramble inside the six-yard box. In the midst of it, goalkeeper Alfred Mikkelsen took a kick to the face. The officials went to video review but ultimately upheld the call on the field, ruling it no foul. The FAU offense responded to tie the game in the 20th minute. Josh Ainge played a through ball to Mamadou Diarra. The two-time American Conference Offensive Player of the Year cut inside and connected on a thunderous strike past the FIU keeper. Four minutes later, the Owls grabbed the lead for the first time, and they would not relinquish it. Ethan Schumaker headed home a corner kick from Aboubacar Traore to send Florida Atlantic into halftime with a 2-1 lead. Diarra scored his second of the night in the 70th minute to double the lead. This time, it was Felipe Santos who played the striker into a dangerous area. Diarra found just enough space to fire off a left-footed strike from just outside the penalty area. The Owls led 3-1 with 20 minutes to go. FIU scored in the 80th minute, but the Panthers would get no closer. The Owls held on for a thrilling 3-2 victory. Diarra was named Offensive Player of the Tournament. Center back Fabrizio Cubeddu earned the Defensive Player of the Tournament award. Mamadou Diarra and the Florida Atlantic Owls poured it all out on the field and now they are champions üèÜüíô#BuiltToRise x #AmericanMSOC pic.twitter.com/2tDFVxthee ‚Äî The American (@American_Conf) November 16, 2025 Caught up with @joeyworthen at today's welcome home rally #WIPüèùÔ∏è pic.twitter.com/bahFnhdXM0 ‚Äî Florida Atlantic Men's Soccer (@FAUMSoccer) November 16, 2025 The Owls have now earned an automatic berth in the NCAA National Championship First Round. They will learn their next opponent when the bracket is announced on Monday, November 17, at 1 p.m. For complete coverage of FAU men's soccer, follow us on X and Instagram (@FAUMSoccer).

column1: Vanterpool Drops 30 as Owls Win Monday Night
column2: BOCA RATON, Fla. ‚Äì Behind a 30-point performance from redshirt sophomore guard Devin Vanterpool, the Florida Atlantic men's basketball team triumphed over Coastal Georgia by a score of 92-63 on Monday night at Eleanor R. Baldwin Arena. The Owls (3-1) took an early 17-3 lead over the Mariners (3-4) and never looked back on the way to recording their second wire-to-wire 20+ point victory. FIRST HALF Back-to-back three-pointers from junior forward Xander Pintelon put the Owls up 17-3 just four minutes in. The Mariners closed the gap to four before back-to-back threes from redshirt freshman guard Amar Amkou and junior guard Kanaan Carlyle put FAU back in front by double digits. 10 unanswered points from the Owls gave them their first 20-point lead with under four minutes to go. A cutting layup from Vanterpool gave him 13 for the half and sent FAU into the locker room with a comfortable 50-33 lead. SECOND HALF Vanterpool opened second-half scoring, the first two of his 17 points in the final period. The Owls regained their 20+ point advantage with Vanterpool scoring five straight, first on a tip-in and then a steal leading to a three-point play on the other end. Another run led by Vanterpool, scoring nine straight points for the Owls, gave him the coveted mark of 30 with over six minutes left, giving him a new career high for the second consecutive game. PRESS CONFERENCE GALLERY Gallery: (11-17-2025) MBB vs. Coastal Georgia STATS & NOTES Vanterpool's 30 points is the most by an Owl in a single game since Johnell Davis in January of 2024. The Owls blocked 10 shots, their second game with double-digit blocks this season. Carlyle's six assists ties his career high. Florida Atlantic outscored Coastal Georgia 46-10 in the paint. The Owls scored 22 second-chance points, while holding the Mariners to three. UP NEXT Florida Atlantic will remain at the Elly, hosting Pacific on Thursday, Nov. 20. Tipoff between the Owls and the Tigers (3-1) is at 7 p.m. on ESPN+. FOLLOW THE OWLS To stay up to date on all things FAU men's basketball, follow the Owls on social media @FAUMBB. Florida Atlantic's 2025-26 season is sponsored by Phil Smith Kia/Phil Smith Acura.

column1: Owls‚Äô Rally Falls Short in NCAA First Round
column2: ORLANDO, Fla. ‚Äì Florida Atlantic men's soccer saw its season come to an end on Thursday night in the First Round of the NCAA Tournament. The Owls mounted a furious second half rally before ultimately falling short in a 3-2 defeat to UCF. The Knights advance to face Georgetown in the second round on Sunday. The Owls owned possession early and had four corner kicks inside the first 10 minutes. The Knights opened the scoring, however, with their first shot on goal in the 15th minute. They doubled the lead in the 24th minute to take a 2-0 advantage into halftime. The visitors cut the deficit to one early in the second half. Oliver Moller-Jensen saved a ball from going over the end line for a goal kick. Mamadou Diarra picked up the loose ball and sent a pass across the six-yard box, where Andreas Raisanen ripped a side-volley past the UCF keeper to make it 2-1. UCF responded just four minutes later to reassert a two-goal lead with 30 minutes to play in the match. The Owls made one final push inside the last 10 minutes. Aboubacar Traore's cross found Diarra, who headed home his ninth goal of the season to make it 3-2 with 9:50 on the clock. In the 88th minute, Eli Conway's shot from the top of the penalty area caromed off the left post and across the goal line but stayed out. That would be the final chance for Florida Atlantic. The final shot count was 14-11 in favor of UCF, with eight on goal compared to six for the Owls. Goalkeeper Alfred Mikkelsen finished with three saves. Postgame with @joeyworthen pic.twitter.com/K8uU1wGBH2 ‚Äî Florida Atlantic Men's Soccer (@FAUMSoccer) November 21, 2025 The Owls finish 2025 with a record of 12-4-2, tying the 2004 team for the second-most wins in a single season. For complete coverage of FAU men's soccer, follow us on X and Instagram (@FAUMSoccer).

column1: Owls Soar Past Tigers in Sunshine Slam Home Game
column2: BOCA RATON, Fla. ‚Äì A strong shooting performance lifted the Florida Atlantic men's basketball team past Pacific in an 82-59 victory on Thursday evening at Eleanor R. Baldwin Arena. The Owls (4-1) shot a season high 55.8% from the field, led by junior guard Kanaan Carlyle's first 20-point performance with FAU. Defensively, they put forth their best performance guarding the perimeter, holding the Tigers (3-2) to 18%. FIRST HALF Redshirt sophomore forward Devin Williams opened scoring on the first possession with a three-pointer. Two three-point plays from Carlyle in the first nine minutes opened up FAU's first double digit lead of the game. A 9-0 run, led by Vanterpool and redshirt sophomore guard Niccolo Moretti helped Florida Atlantic enter the locker room with a 40-28 lead. SECOND HALF Shots continued to fall for the Owls, shooting 15-for-23 from the field and converting half of their three-pointers. Three consecutive shots from beyond the arc, courtesy of two triples by Elohim and a four-point play from Carlyle, put the Owls up by 20, a lead that grew to as much as 26. PRESS CONFERENCE GALLERY Gallery: (11-20-2025) MBB vs. Pacific STATS & NOTES Carlyle shot 7-for-12 from the field and a perfect 4-for-4 in the second half. Vanterpool recorded another complete game, with five rebounds, three assists, three blocks, and two steals to go with his 12 points. The Owls tallied eight blocks after notching 10 the previous game. Williams and Vanterpool each had three. FAU won the assist battle 15-8. UP NEXT Florida Atlantic will head to Daytona as a member of the Sunshine Slam's Beach Bracket. Its first opponent is LMU, set for Monday, Nov. 24 at 8:30 p.m. on CBS Sports Network. FOLLOW THE OWLS To stay up to date on all things FAU men's basketball, follow the Owls on social media @FAUMBB. Florida Atlantic's 2025-26 season is sponsored by Phil Smith Kia/Phil Smith Acura.

MOBILE, Ala. ‚Äì The Florida Atlantic Owls fell short on the road at South Alabama on Thursday, dropping a 70-63 contest at the Mitchell Center. The Owls fall to 2-2, while South Alabama improves to 4-1 on the season. HOW IT HAPPENED The Owls started off hot as a fast break layup from Jess Moors capped off a 10-1 opening run with FAU leading by nine at the opening media break. Grace Carstensen's first triple of the day kept the Owls' lead at six, 15-9, with just under two minutes to play in the first, but the Jaguars closed the quarter on a 6-1 run to cut the FAU lead to just one, 16-15, at the end of the first. The two squads traded baskets to open the second, battling through three ties to a 22-22 stalemate with 4:41 to play in the half. The Jaguars went on an 8-3 scoring run to hold a five-point advantage, 30-25, with 1:28 to go in the half. However, Carstensen knocked down her second triple of the day to make it a one-possession game at the break, 30-28. Vivian Onugha tied things back up at 30-30 off a layup to open the third. A pair of free throws from Moors kept things within one, 33-32, through the 7:11-minute mark. However, the Jaguars then scored 13 unanswered points to take their first double-figure lead of the night, 46-32. The Owls started to battle back, cutting the lead to eight, 51-43, with a minute to play in the third, but USA scored four more to close out the quarter, making it 55-43 entering the final 10 minutes of play. The Jaguars knocked down a three to open the fourth, pushing their lead to its largest of the night at 15, 58-43. South Alabama maintained a 15-point advantage through a 63-48 lead with 4:41 remaining. The Owls rallied late on a 13-2 run to cut the Jaguars' lead to just four, 65-61, with 1:27 to play, but a couple of costly turnovers caused the Owls' rally to fall just short as South Alabama took the contest, 70-63. HEAR FROM HEAD COACH LEANN FREELAND "Disappointing loss to South Alabama. Their pressure and size definitely influenced our performance. We turned the ball over way too much and didn't execute as well as we needed to compete in their arena. We just have to get better." NOTES AND TEAM STATS Four Owls scored in double-figures, led by Onugha with a game-best 17 points, shooting 55 percent (6-of-11) from the field and 83 percent (5-of-6) from the line. Moors and Destyne Jackson tied with 11 points apiece, and Michiyah Simmons rounded out the Owls' double-figure scorers with 10 points on the night. Jackson dished out a game-high three assists to lead the team. Moors led the Owls in steals, collecting a season-high six. Haley Walker led the Owls on the glass, collecting a team-high six rebounds. Madi Gewirtz recorded the Owls' sole block in the contest. The Owls outscored the Jaguars in the first quarter, 16-15, and in the fourth quarter, 20-15. Florida Atlantic also outshot South Alabama from 3-point range, 33.3 percent to 29.4 percent, and at the line, 82.8 percent to 72.4 percent. FAU also held an advantage in fast break points, outscoring USA 18-11 in transition. UP NEXT The Owls return to Paradise next week as they get set to host the Florida Gators for a 7 p.m. tip on Monday, Nov. 24, inside Eleanor R. Baldwin Arena and on ESPN+. FOLLOW THE OWLS To stay up to date with everything Florida Atlantic women's basketball, follow @FAUWBB_Hoops on X and @FAUWBB on Instagram, or like Florida Atlantic Women's Basketball on Facebook. Florida Atlantic's 2025-26 season is sponsored by Flagler Credit Union.

column1: Owls Set Four Program Records on Day Two of Patriot Invite
column2: FAIRFAX, Va. ‚Äì Highlighted by four new program records and one new freshman record, the Florida Atlantic men's and women's swimming and diving teams completed day two of the George Mason Patriot Invitational with the women atop of the team standings and the men closely following. Through two days of action, the Owls have won eight different events, resulting in four new program records. Team Scores Post Day Two (WOMEN): Florida Atlantic: 686 Towson: 613 Richmond: 459 Marist: 369 George Mason: 366 American: 361 Monmouth: 181 UNC-Wilmington: 62 (MEN): Towson: 775.5 Florida Atlantic: 716.5 George Mason: 497 Marist: 337.5 Monmouth: 306.5 American: 218 Marymount: 134 UNC-Wilmington: 84 QUICK HITS Day One The Owls picked up two events on day one of relay action. Megan Drover-Smith, Bilu Bianchi, Maja Piotrowicz, Izzy Jones took home first place in the 200 medley relay finishing a time of 1:41.07. The men's 800 free team of James Shevchenko, Rush Clark, Sabian Branch and Daniel Laureyssens swam to first in a time of 6:28.86, a new pool record. Day two FAU had a strong day leaving day two with four new program records and a new freshman record. Laureyssens continues to break records for FAU, this setting a new 50 free program record in the prelims before besting it in the finals, swimming 19.57. Jones rebroke her own 50 free school record, lowering the time to 22.82. Freshman Noah Reeves set a new freshman program record in the 50 free during the prelims and finals, recording a time of 19.94 in the finals. In the 500 free, Shevchenko won the event (4:22.60) while setting a new meet record. Talitha McEwan won the 500 free (4:51.10). Junior Trevor Kuhn took home the win on the 1mtr diving totaling a score of 307.35. Augusta Ness placed second on the 3mtr diving for the Owls (281.85). Day two closed with the men's 200 free relay smashing the program record. The team of Leyton Roe, Reeves, Clark, and Laureyssens won the event in a new school record time of 1:18.37. ON DECK The Owls will be back tomorrow for day three of the George Mason Patriot Invitational begins with prelim action starting at 10:00 am with finals slated to start at 6:00 pm. SCHEDULE For the full 2025-26 swim & dive schedule, click HERE. ROSTER For the full 2025-26 swim & dive roster, click HERE. FOLLOW THE OWLS For complete coverage from the meet and more FAU swimming & diving news, follow along on social media platforms (@fauswimdive).

BOCA RATON, Fla. ‚Äì Florida Atlantic football will play host to UConn this Saturday, Nov. 22 at 3 p.m. The game is scheduled to air on ESPN+ and on FoxSports 640 South Florida. Leading the Owls on Saturday will be redshirt senior DL Naejaun Barber, who will be featured in Season 10, Episode 15 of the Inside the Owls' Burrow television show, which airs each week on FanDuel Sports Network Florida. Barber, who hails from Hopkins, South Carolina, transferred to the Owls in the summer of 2025. following FAU's defensive coordinator Brett Dewhurst from Coastal Carolina. Prior to Coastal, Barber played two seasons at South Carolina State. This season, he has taken advantage of every opportunity and has become a starter on the Owls' defensive line. He set a new FAU career high with six tackles a week ago and has totaled 31 on the season. He has bested his statistical line in nearly every category this season. column1: No. 6-seed Owls set for American Quarterfinal vs. No. 3-seed Tulsa
column2: TAMPA, Fla. ‚Äì The No. 6-seed Florida Atlantic Owls are set to open postseason play on Friday, Nov. 21, taking on No. 3-seed Tulsa in the first round of the American Conference Tournament in Tampa, Florida. First serve is scheduled for 7:30 p.m. ET at The Corral on ESPN+. A LOOK AT THE OWLS The No. 6-seed Florida Atlantic Owls enter postseason play at 19-10 overall and 10-6 in American play. The Owls' 19 regular-season wins mark the program's third-straight season with 18 or more wins and the eighth-most single-season wins in program history. The Owls are led offensively by American Second Team All-Conference honoree Olivia Hart. Hart boasts a team-best 3.59 kills per set. Anna Hartman and Erin Morrissey are also offensive leaders for the Owls, ranking second and third on the team, averaging 2.70 and 2.37 kills per set, respectively. The Owls' assist leaders are All-Freshman Team honoree Emsley Venard and Victoria Hensley. Venard boasts a team-leading 604 assists, averaging 5.98 assists per set, while Hensley ranks second on the team with 510 assists, dishing out 5.0 assists per set. Libero Isabelle Northam leads the Owls' back row, boasting a team-best 412 digs, averaging 4.20 digs per set. Hart ranks second on the team in digs with 290, averaging 2.84 per set. At the net, Florida Atlantic's block is led by Maggie Allred, Kayla Richardson, and Libby Ashline. Allred has registered a team-best 107 blocks this season, averaging 1.13 blocks per set. Richardson ranks second with 68 blocks, averaging 0.69 blocks per set, while Ashline ranks third in blocks with 67, but second in blocks per set, averaging 0.96 blocks per set. SCOUTING TULSA Tulsa enters the American Tournament as the No. 3 seed, finishing the regular season with a 22-6 overall record and a 12-4 mark in conference play. The Golden Hurricane have six hitters averaging over 2.0 kills per set, led by Olivia Vance, Beth Bayless, and Lauren Eitler. Vance boasts a team-leading 2.79 per set, while Bayless ranks second, averaging 2.58 kills per set. Eitler leads Tulsa with 247 kills and ranks third on the team, tallying 2.52 kills per set this season. Brayden Hipp, who garnered American Conference Setter of the Year honors, leads Tulsa and the American in assists, dishing out 985 assists and averaging 10.05 assists per set this season. The Golden Hurricane's back row is led by Lauren Patterson, who has recorded a team-best 357 digs, averaging 3.64 digs per set. Tulsa's blocking leader is Jill Hanson, the American Conference Freshman of the Year, who boasts a team-best 106 blocks, averaging 1.08 blocks per set. SERIES HISTORY Friday's American Tournament first-round matchup marks the fifth all-time meeting between Florida Atlantic and Tulsa. The series is tied 2-2, however, the Owls were victorious in the last meeting between the two programs, capturing a 3-0 sweep earlier this season on Nov. 2 in Boca Raton. UP NEXT With an opening-round win, the Owls would prepare to face the winner of No. 2 South Florida/No. 7 Charlotte in the semifinals on Saturday, Nov. 22, at 3 p.m. ET. The championship match is scheduled for 1 p.m. ET on Sunday, Nov. 23. All tournament matches will air live on ESPN+. FOLLOW THE OWLS To stay up to date with everything Florida Atlantic volleyball, follow @FAUVolleyball on X and Instagram, or like FAU Volleyball on Facebook.

column1: Owls Match Graduation Success Rate Record for Third Straight Year
column2: BOCA RATON, Fla. ‚Äì The NCAA released Graduation Success Rate (GSR) data this week, showing that 90 percent of Florida Atlantic freshmen student-athletes receiving scholarship aid, graduated within six years ‚Äì matching a school record for the third consecutive year. Florida Atlantic has steadily improved its overall GSR in each of the seven years under Vice President and Director of Athletics Brian White, including three straight years of a record 90 percent. "Consistently achieving a record high Graduation Success Rate is a point of pride for the athletics department and the university," said White. "Our student-athletes remain steadfast in their commitment to academics, as evidenced by this, our high APR, and our 20 consecutive semesters with a cumulative GPA of better than 3.0. We continue to compete at championship levels on and off the field and I am grateful for the dedication displayed by our student-athletes, coaches, and staff to our mission." Florida Atlantic was one of nine schools from the American Conference to meet the 90-percent threshold, while a total of 10 FAU teams achieved a 100 percent GSR: men's basketball, men's golf, men's swimming & diving, men's tennis, women's golf, softball, women's soccer, women's swimming & diving, women's track and volleyball. The GSR is based on student-athletes who entered college as freshmen from 2015-18 and allows for the removal of those individuals from the cohort who left FAU in good academic standing. #WIP

BOCA RATON, Fla. ‚Äì Week 11 of the 2025 NFL season is in the books with three former Florida Atlantic Owls seeing action and three touchdowns resulting from it. Here's a rundown of how each performed during the 11th week (All gametimes listed below are Eastern): Active Owls (3) #0 Azeez Al-Shaair | LB | Houston Texans - Al-Shaair took the field for all of Houston's 59 defensive snaps in their 16-13 win over the divisional rival Tennessee Titans. He recorded six tackles and is now up to a team-leading 65 on the season for the league's top scoring defense. Texans' Record: 5-5 Next Game: vs. Buffalo ‚Äì Thursday, 8:15 p.m. (Prime Video) #42 James Pierre | CB | Pittsburgh Steelers - Making his first start of the season, Pierre put forth one of the best games of his career, culminating in his first career touchdown. He made six tackles, his most in a game since 2016 and had Pittsburgh's final score in their 34-12 victory over the AFC North foe Cincinnati Bengals, scooping up a fumble and returning it 34 yards untouched into the end zone. STEELERS SCOOP AND SCORE.CINvsPIT on CBS/Paramount+https://t.co/HkKw7uXVnt pic.twitter.com/yFfenOX5FB‚Äî NFL (@NFL) November 16, 2025 Steelers' Record: 6-4 Next Game: at Chicago ‚Äì Sunday, 1 p.m. (CBS) #26 Devin Singletary | RB | New York Giants - "Motor" tallied two touchdowns, his first multi-score game since 2022, and ran for a season high 44 yards. Singletary's touchdowns, both in the first half, were his first scores of the year. The first was on the Giants' opening drive to take a 7-0 lead and the final came at the goal line to tie the game at 13 apiece. New York ultimately fell to the Green Bay Packers by a score of 27-20.
